Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper on Combining Interactive Evolution with Novelty Search
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=y4XvV16PCmeqlz9-ZIyjYAWVnRJvuwi64ISjIxSjiIX_C70F0oOj
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune
From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>


--Apple-Mail=_D1A47C53-334C-42A4-93E1-522020AD20D8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hi Joel,

Please see below. 

> It sounds like I pretty heavily confused wh=
at you were trying to say :)
> 
> I can see what you are getting at with th=
e 'leveling-up' idea from the distribution of points in NS. And I think ult=
imately, looking at the ancestors of a successful maze navigator would help=
 to investigate what is happening there more concretely. My hunch would be =
that the immediate ancestors of the ones that 'popped' into the new areas w=
ere also wall-followers, but with less capability to make hard turns so the=
y would tend to get stuck in the interior sorts of areas, and that the popp=
ing was due less to a incredible leap in abilities as much as a more subtle=
 refinement of skills that facilitated a non-linear leap in the behavior sp=
ace; or maybe that is what you are implying as well? 

I don=92t know what =
the progression looks like, but your hypothesis sounds likely. I think it w=
ould be great to see a video of each robot in the champion lineage to know =
for sure. You don=92t happen to have that data, do you? If so, would it be =
hard to create such a video?

> I can understand the desire to understand m=
ore clearly what is going on and there's room for future follow-up studies =
to answer the interesting questions you're raising less speculatively.
> 
>=
 My guess for why Fitness has a paucity of intermediate points, similar to =
NS, is that both methods don't have much vested interest in finding those s=
pecific points. Fitness actively selects against them given that they are f=
urther from the goal than the end of the cul-de-sac,

But once some robots =
make the turn in the lower right corner, any robot closer to the goal would=
 be selected for vs. those corner robots (similar to the Waypoint treatment=
). We do see some orgs in the bottom-right corner (and the ensuing hallway =
above it), so it=92s a bit surprising that something similar to waypoint ev=
olution doesn=92t take over at that point, no?

> and basically the only wa=
y it can solve the maze is to get very lucky and have an individual pop in =
very close to the goal. NS is interested in discovering new points but is i=
ndifferent to which ones it finds, and so it follows wherever novelty natur=
ally leads, which in this case goes to the goal before it leads to the inte=
rior zones. The other methods have more interest in the interior points to =
varying degrees, which might explain the distributional differences.

I don=
=92t think NA-IEC has more interest in intermediate points. The human evalu=
ates must have simply never seen that robot that suddenly goes all the way =
to the goal (otherwise they would have been done). In other words, NA-IEC n=
ever saw/produced the non-linear skill jump. I still don=92t have a good un=
derstanding as to why. I=92d be interesting if you or anyone else out there=
 reading this has any additional hypotheses. 

> 
> > Why don=92t you think=
 the absence of points in the 2nd half of the =93path to the goal=94 indica=
tes general exploratory skills, such as wall following? Isn=92t that precis=
ely the explanation you provide for why the points don=92t exist? Those rob=
ots are wall following in parts of the maps (and thus situations) they have=
 not encountered before, and seem to do just fine, so shouldn=92t those ski=
lls lead to general exploratory skills in other maps?
> 
> That last senten=
ce is a subtle elegant argument that I don't think I've heard before, which=
 I very much like, and somewhat convinces me about the distribution providi=
ng evidence for exploratory skills. In that context, I can see how that sam=
e argument would explain why you found the Fitness solutions are as good at=
 exploration as the NS ones -- when very rarely in the fitness runs, an ind=
ividual "jumps out" of the local optimum and almost immediately solves the =
maze (despite having almost no evolutionary experience in that part of the =
maze), by virtue of its lack of evolutionary experience it is likely to be =
general -- i.e. it just successfully navigated a whole bunch of the maze it=
 had never encountered before. In this case, the heavy local optimum is alm=
ost acting like some kind of 'generality sieve'. 
> 
> Also, it gets my min=
d thinking that if you wanted to encourage more general exploratory skills =
you would explicitly design a map with increasingly varied experiences (dif=
ferent kinds of turns, etc.) over those provided by the hard map (which I d=
id not design to induce general exploration). 
> 
> While I really like you=
r argument about why gaps might provide evidence for general exploration, i=
t seems like  often exposure to a single idiosyncratic environment like the=
 hard maze offers only a limited potential for generalization, so it could =
be that encouraging a measure like reactivity that is designed to incentivi=
ze more general policies, in addition to NS alone, might be helpful as well=
 (or noisy multiple trials, where you might average an individual's behavio=
r vector over those trials).
> 
> Sorry for the misunderstanding earlier, I=
 think I much better appreciate your position now, the point about behavior=
-space gaps indicating generalization over unseen experience I found pretty=
 subtle and clever.
> 

Great. Thanks. It does seem like a very cool phenom=
enon that=92s occurring. My instincts tell me that by understanding it bett=
er we could harness it to improve the complexity of evolved robots. One pat=
h is along the ideas you suggest for increasing generality, which I like an=
d hope someone explores. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Assistant Professor
Co=
mputer Science
University of Wyoming
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com




>=
 Best,
> Joel
> 
> 
> 

--Apple-Mail=_D1A47C53-334C-42A4-93E1-522020AD20D8
